message.raw:
a (hopefully temporary) fix for bug #610.
This is in the h5_lock module, which is where I was hacking things onto h5py anyway. I've disabled the actual h5_locking for the moment, until I make a few changes to pythonlib to accomodate it, such as BLACS worker processes not holding the file open for minutes at a time while they program a device (I'm looking at you, novatech) when they could easily close the file prior to programming.

Added imports everywhere needed throughout pythonlib

message.raw:
Added h5_lock, which wraps network-based locking around the opening and closing of hdf5 files. If files are opened in any mode other than read only ('r'), then a redis lock will be acquired whilst the file is open.
Usage:
import h5_lock
h5_lock.turn_locks_on('bec.physics.monash.edu.au') # redis server
import h5py
# away you go
message.html:
Added h5_lock, which wraps network-based locking around the opening and closing of hdf5 files. If files are opened in any mode other than read only ('r'), then a redis lock will be acquired whilst the file is open.
Usage:
import h5_lock
h5_lock.turn_locks_on('bec.physics.monash.edu.au') # redis server
import h5py

away you go

message.raw:
fixed bug in restoring modified times

we now check to see if files have been removed from the list of files to check, and remove those missing files from the list of modified times. This way if a files is removed from the list of files to check, and then readded, it won't show up as being modified if it happened to have been modified when we weren't monitoring it. I believe that this is the desired bahaviour!

message.raw:
Added a module for caching the location of imports. Use like so:

from filewatcher.modulebooster import enable
enable()

It tracks where imports were found and saves the locations to a file,
so that their location on the filesystem doesn't need to be looked up again.

so that their location on the filesystem doesn't need to be looked up again.

message.raw:
Promoted the lock acquisition to happen at a higher level so that modulewatcher does not even *read* sys.modules unless it has the lock.
This is to work around a bug whereby h5py appears not to be threadsafe and is corrupting simultaneously running threads...but seeminly only when they do a dict.items() loop. Very strage.

message.raw:
Applied a fix for a bug whereby modulewatcher might unload modules whilst an import is in progress, leading to potential inconsistencies.
Now it holds the import lock whilst it modifies sys.modules.

Also added an attribute unloader_lock, which users should hold whenever they want to disable the automatic unloading of modules.
message.html:
Applied a fix for a bug whereby modulewatcher might unload modules whilst an import is in progress, leading to potential inconsistencies.
Now it holds the import lock whilst it modifies sys.modules.

Also added an attribute unloader_lock, which users should hold whenever they want to disable the automatic unloading of modules.

Also added an attribute unloader_lock, which users should hold whenever they want to disable the automatic unloading of modules.

message.raw:
Applied an attempted workaround to what appears to be a python bug.

The modulewatcher.ModuleWatcher.check_and_unload function would crash sometimes if a garbage collection cycle was running at the same time
I am not sure which part of it specifically, as adding printlines seemed to decreas the probability of a collision.

The attempted workaround is to disable garbage collection and manually check once a cycle if garbage needs to be collected.

message.raw:
Fixed a rare bug where the first file in the list of files to watch was temporarily unavailable when getting the modified time but was available when checking if the path exists.

This bug may have occurred often, but if it was not the first file in the list of files, then it would have used the modified time for the previous file. No obvious error would have been reported, (file may have been shown to be modified) but it was still incorrect behaviour.

message.raw: Fixed a bug in ModuleWatcher where it wouldn't know about changes in sys.stderr and would print to the old stderr (which might not even exist anymore). On Linux if it doesn't exist no biggie, you just don't get the messages. In Windows, you get an IOError: invalid file descriptor. So ModuleWatcher just prints to sys.stderr now rather than keeping track of its own error stream.
message.html: Fixed a bug in ModuleWatcher where it wouldn't know about changes in sys.stderr and would print to the old stderr (which might not even exist anymore). On Linux if it doesn't exist no biggie, you just don't get the messages. In Windows, you get an IOError: invalid file descriptor. So ModuleWatcher just prints to sys.stderr now rather than keeping track of its own error stream.

values.message: Fixed a bug in ModuleWatcher where it wouldn't know about changes in sys.stderr and would print to the old stderr (which might not even exist anymore). On Linux if it doesn't exist no biggie, you just don't get the messages. In Windows, you get an IOError: invalid file descriptor. So ModuleWatcher just prints to sys.stderr now rather than keeping track of its own error stream.

message.raw: Modified how subprocesses pipe output to parent processes. No longer do parents need to filter the output of the children to see what is stdout and what is stderr and what's something else of interest. Now parents pass in a port when calling the child, and children send their output directly to an OutputBox or similar via zmq push, no filtering step required. Also, since this is using raw zmq sockets, it ought to be faster.
message.html: Modified how subprocesses pipe output to parent processes. Now parents pass in a port when calling the child, and children send their output directly to an OutputBox or similar via zmq push, no filtering step required. Also, since this is using raw zmq sockets, it ought to be faster.

message.raw: Added a try/except block so that if gtk is not installed, you don't get a horrible crash!
message.html: Added a try/except block so that if gtk is not installed, you don't get a horrible crash!

values.message: Added a try/except block so that if gtk is not installed, you don't get a horrible crash!

message.raw: Added an option to supress re-raising so that gtk_handler can be used to display messages without causing an actual crash, if desired. However I changed my mind and ended up not using this. It's poor form I think, since we're getting used to regarding gtk_handler dialogs as indicating a fatal error. We'd better not use them to indicate recoverable errors too, I think it's useful for the two kinds of errors to be visibly distinct. Maybe I'll make a gentler looking dialog box for non-fatal errors. Or not, don't have a use case right now.

message.raw: Now has logging support. Do 'import excepthook' to just enable the graphical error message, and call excepthook.set_logger(logger) to set up the logger that you want unhanded exceptions and warnings to be logged to.
message.html: Now has logging support. Do 'import excepthook' to just enable the graphical error message, and call excepthook.set_logger(logger) to set up the logger that you want unhanded exceptions and warnings to be logged to.

message.raw:
Added excepthook module.

type 'import excepthook' at the top of any python script, and errors in it will be caught and displayed graphically by GTK.
